(born 20 January 1991) is a professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for {{English football updater|Fulham}} club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] and the [[Scotland national football team|Scotland national team]]. Cairney has previously played for [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] and [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]]. Born in England, he made his full international debut for [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] in March 2017. Cairney had previously represented Scotland at [[Scotland national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[Scotland national under-21 football team|under-21]] levels.
==Early life== Cairney was born and raised in [[Nottingham]], Nottinghamshire, to a Scottish father, who worked as a miner and then as a taxi driver.<ref name="Cairney Daily Record"/> He also revealed that his father would take him to Scotland and watch [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] as a youngster.<ref name="Cairney Daily Record"/> When he was about 15 or 16, he worked for Barclays Bank for work experience. He described this as the "worst two weeks of [his] life!" and had to work 9–5 in a bank and wear suit and tie for two weeks.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rovers.co.uk/news/2014/september/getting-personal-with-tom-cairney/|title='Getting Personal' with Tom Cairney|publisher=Blackburn Rovers F.C.|date=15 September 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170906205737/https://www.rovers.co.uk/news/2014/september/getting-personal-with-tom-cairney/|archivedate=7 September 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Early career=== Cairney was released from the [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] youth system at the age of 16 after being told he was too small. He had been with the club since the age of seven.<ref name="BBC Radio Humberside">{{Cite episode|title=Sports Talk|network=BBC|station=BBC Radio Humberside|location=Hull|airdate=10 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Hull look likely to benefit from Cairney's keenness to prove Leeds wrong|url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/sport/football/hull-look-likely-to-benefit-from-cairney-s-keenness-to-prove-leeds-wrong-1-2559976 |newspaper=The Yorkshire Post |location=Leeds |date=2 February 2010|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> Reflecting on his time at Leeds United, he said: "To be honest it crushed me, it crushed me a lot, I was with Leeds from I was seven to 16 so it was a big part of my life. I was going there three-four times a week, missing days of schools, and obviously my mum and dad had put a lot into it too. So getting released at 16, it just felt like, ‘oh no, after all that effort’. But I was determined I would not stop there. I went to Hull and they offered me a YTS as they obviously saw something. And from 16–18 I shot up in height and then it went back to my footballing ability. From getting released at 16 to making my Premier League debut – if you wrote it down you wouldn't believe it. I owe a lot to (then Hull manager) [[Phil Brown (footballer, born 1959)|Phil Brown]] as he believed in me. I think the academy staff at Leeds must have got a bit of a shock when they saw me playing in the Premier League! I don’t know what happened to them but I think they may have got a telling off!"<ref>{{cite news|title=Leeds United release left me crushed but it also inspired me, says Blackburn Rovers star Tom Cairney|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/11315829.Leeds_United_release_left_me_crushed_but_it_also_inspired_me__says_Blackburn_Rovers_star_Tom_Cairney/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=3 July 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref>
===Hull City=== [[File:Tom Cairney 1.png|thumb|upright|Cairney playing for [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] in 2011]]
[[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] gave Cairney a chance when they signed him to a youth contract in 2007.<ref name="BBC Radio Humberside"/> Cairney was named as Hull's Young Player of the Year for the [[2008–09 Hull City A.F.C. season|2008–09]] season.<ref name=YPOTY>{{cite web |url=http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/NewsDetail/0,,10338~1726932,00.html |title=City Record Friendly Victory |publisher=Hull City A.F.C. |date=19 July 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301012909/http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/NewsDetail/0,,10338~1726932,00.html |archivedate=1 March 2012 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> For this, he signed a two-year contract with the club in June 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dean Windass released as Hull make changes|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/hull-city/5429378/Dean-Windass-released-as-Hull-make-changes.html|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=2 June 2009|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref>
He played for Hull against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in the final of the pre-season [[Premier League Asia Trophy]] in Beijing on 31 July 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.premierleague.com/page/Headlines/0,,12306~1739344,00.html|title=Tottenham Hotspur 3–0 Hull City|publisher=Premier League|date=31 July 2009|accessdate=7 September 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090803160728/http://www.premierleague.com/page/Headlines/0%2C%2C12306~1739344%2C00.html|archivedate=7 September 2017|deadurl=yes}}</ref> His first-team debut came against [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] in the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] on 25 August 2009, when he opened the scoring with a curling long-range effort as Hull won 3–1.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tonight's Teams|url=http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/NewsDetail/0,,10338~1768639,00.html|publisher=Hull City A.F.C.| date=25 August 2009|accessdate=7 June 2013|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20120301012923/http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/NewsDetail/0,,10338~1768639,00.html|archivedate=1 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8203204.stm|title=Hull 3–1 Southend|publisher =BBC Sport|date=25 August 2009|accessdate=26 August 2009}}</ref> He went on to make his [[Premier League]] debut on 30 January 2010 in a 2–2 draw against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Brett|first=Oliver|title=Hull City 2–2 Wolverhampton Wanderers|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8482870.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 January 2010|accessdate=30 January 2010}}</ref> On 7 March 2010, Cairney scored his first league goal for Hull in a 5–1 defeat against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], an impressive volley from outside the area.<ref>{{cite news|title=Everton 5–1 Hull|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8549507.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=7 March 2010|accessdate=8 March 2010|last=Reekie|first=Harry}}</ref> Cairney signed a new three-year contract with the club on 31 March 2010.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cairney signs Tigers deal|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6057304,00.html|publisher=Sky Sports |date=31 March 2010|accessdate=10 June 2013}}</ref><ref name="Tom Cairney, Player Profile">{{cite web|title=Tom Cairney, Player Profile|url=http://www.hullcityafc.net/team/player-profile/index.aspx?playerid=431312&tcmuri=29767|publisher=Hull City A.F.C.|date=15 July 2012|accessdate=10 June 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120820023208/http://www.hullcityafc.net/team/player-profile/index.aspx?playerid=431312&tcmuri=29767|archivedate=7 September 2017|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Having been given a first team opportunity later in the season,<ref>{{cite news|title=Return of Hunt is perfect for Tigers|url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/sport/football/return-of-hunt-is-perfect-for-tigers-1-2570174 |newspaper=The Yorkshire Post |location=Leeds |date=8 April 2010|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> he made the total of 14 appearance and scoring once for the side.
Following Hull's relegation, Cairney began to establish himself in the first team in the 2010–11 season.<ref name="Tom Cairney, Player Profile"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Hull City manager Pearson must sell before he can buy|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/8856380.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 July 2010|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> He scored one goal, a curling free kick against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] that helped Hull to their first away victory in 30 games.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/9021294.stm|title=Norwich 0–2 Hull|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 September 2010|accessdate=11 December 2012}}</ref> In January 2011, he signed a contract extension with the club, keeping him until 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dawson Signs New Hull Extension|url=http://www.hullcity-mad.co.uk/news/tmnw/dawson_signs_new_hull_extension_615508/index.shtml|publisher=Hull City Mad|date=3 January 2011|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> Despite suffering an injury,<ref>{{cite news|title=Chester Braced For Tigers Bow|url=http://www.hullcity-mad.co.uk/news/tmnw/chester_braced_for_tigers_bow_619779/index.shtml|publisher=Hull City Mad|date=14 January 2011|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> Cairney made the total of 23 appearances during the 2010–11 season.
In the 2011–12 season, Cairney continued to feature in the first team and then set up a double assists, in a 3–2 win over [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] on 22 October 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hull City 3–2 Watford|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/15319572.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=22 October 2011|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> He then scored his first goal of the season on 7 January 2012, in a 3–1 win over [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] in the third round of the FA Cup.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hull City 3 – 1 Ipswich Town|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/16371412.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=7 January 2012|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> Despite suffering a foot injury,<ref>{{cite news|title=Hull City 2 Nottingham Forest 1: Tigers see off Forest|url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/sport/football/hull-city/hull-city-2-nottingham-forest-1-tigers-see-off-forest-1-4471922 |newspaper=The Yorkshire Post |location=Leeds |date=27 April 2012|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> Cairney made a total of 29 appearances for Hull in the 2011–12 season.<ref name=sb1112/>
At the start of the 2012–13 season, Cairney played the vital role, in a 3–2 loss against [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] in the second round of the League Cup on 28 August 2012, when he set up two Hull City's goals in the match.<ref>{{cite news|title=Doncaster Rovers hit back to edge thriller|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/doncaster-vs-hull-city/report/273450|publisher=Sky Sports|date=28 August 2012|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> However, during the match, he sustained a serious knee injury, following a reckless tackle by Doncaster's [[James Husband (footballer)|James Husband]] in a League Cup tie. Steve Bruce later described the challenge as a "horror tackle".<ref>{{cite news|title=Hull City boss Steve Bruce angry about 'horror tackle'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19409100|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 August 2012|accessdate=29 August 2012}}</ref> After over three months out injured,<ref>{{cite news|title=Cairney Eyes Promotion|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11714/8340226/cairney-eyes-promotion|publisher=Sky Sports|date=17 December 2012|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> Cairney returned to fitness on 8 December 2012, appearing on the bench for Hull's away victory over [[Watford F.C.|Watford]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Watford 1–2 Hull City|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20564877|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 December 2012|accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> Cairney made his return the following week at home to Huddersfield coming on as a 63rd-minute substitute for teammate Corry Evans.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20650326|title=Hull City 2–0 Huddersfield Town|date=15 December 2012|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=15 December 2012}}</ref> In the third round of the FA Cup against [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] on 5 January 2013, he set up a goal for [[Nick Proschwitz]], in a 1–1 draw to lead to a third round replay.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nick Proschwitz earns Hull 1–1 draw against Leyton Orient in FA Cup third round|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/hull-city-vs-leyton-or/report/281093|publisher=Sky Sports|date=5 January 2013|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> In the third round replay, he scored a winning goal, in a 2–1 win to send them through to the next round.<ref>{{cite news|title= FA Cup: Tom Cairney struck late on as Hull City beat Leyton Orient 2–1|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/leyton-or-vs-hull-city/report/281466|publisher=Sky Sports|date=15 January 2013|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> Although he appeared less and remained on the substitute bench for the rest of the season,<ref>{{cite news|title=Cairney: There’s no reason why Rovers can’t make a charge towards the play-offs|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/10930292.Cairney__There___s_no_reason_why_Rovers_can___t_make_a_charge_towards_the_play_offs/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=11 January 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> Cairney went on to make a total of 14 appearances and scoring once for the side, as Hull City promoted to the Premier League.
===Blackburn Rovers=== [[File:Tom Cairney.jpg|thumb|upright|Cairney playing for [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] in 2014]]
On 1 August 2013, Cairney joined [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] on loan until January.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rovers.co.uk/news/article/rovers-clinch-cairney-deal-960482.aspx|title=Rovers clinch Cairney deal|date=1 August 2013|publisher=Blackburn Rovers Official Website|accessdate=1 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130804100751/http://www.rovers.co.uk/news/article/rovers-clinch-cairney-deal-960482.aspx|archivedate=7 September 2017|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
He made his debut in a 1–1 draw against [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], as a 77th-minute substitute for [[Alex Marrow]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Derby County 1 Blackburn Rovers 1|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/23480906|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=5 August 2013}}</ref> Two days later, Cairney made his full debut for the club in an eventful League Cup clash with [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]], scoring one and providing one assist, before being sent off for the first time in his career after two bookable offences.<ref>{{cite news|title=Carlisle United 3–3 Blackburn Rovers|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23513169|date=7 August 2013|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=8 August 2013}}</ref> Cairney equalised for Blackburn in a 5–2 victory over [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] on 24 August, opening his Championship account for the club.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23736833|title=Blackburn Rovers 5–2 Barnsley|date=24 August 2013|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref> Since joining Blackburn Rovers, Cairney established himself in the first team there, having quickly made an impact.<ref>{{cite news|title=Blackburn Rovers star eyes Scotland call|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/10631356.Blackburn_Rovers_star_eyes_Scotland_call/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=23 August 2013|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Tom Cairney: Blackburn Rovers will be a force next season|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/11263118.Cairney__Blackburn_Rovers_will_be_a_force_next_season/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=7 June 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> He then set up two goals on 1 January 2014, in a 2–1 win over Leeds United.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sky Bet Championship: Gary Bowyer working on Tom Cairney deal after Blackburn beat Leeds 2–1|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11676/9097427/sky-bet-championship-gary-bowyer-working-on-tom-cairney-deal-after-blackburn-beat-leeds-2-1|publisher=Sky Sports|date=2 January 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> The next day, on 2 January 2014, his move to Blackburn was made permanent after a successful first half of the season on loan. Cairney said: "I'm very pleased to sign permanently – that was a goal of mine when I came on loan in August."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rovers.co.uk/news/article/double-deal-done-1270797.aspx|title=Double Deal Done!|date=2 January 2014|publisher=Blackburn Rovers Official Website|accessdate=2 January 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102193710/http://www.rovers.co.uk/news/article/double-deal-done-1270797.aspx|archivedate=7 September 2017|deadurl=yes}}</ref> After completing this permanent deal, Cairney scored his second league for Blackburn Rovers, both of them coming against Barnsley on 28 January 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sky Bet Championship: Barnsley recover to draw with Blackburn at Ewood Park|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/barnsley-vs-blackburn/report/287990|publisher=Sky Sports|date=28 January 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> The local newspaper [[The Lancashire Telegraph|Lancashire Telegraph]] named him as the top performer for January.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cairney is Blackburn Rovers' top performer for January|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/10975818.Cairney_is_Blackburn_Rovers__top_performer_for_January/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=30 January 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> However, after being sidelined with ankle injury, which he sustained against [[Reading F.C.|Reading]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Blackburn Rovers ace Tom Cairney will not be rushed|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/11036895.Blackburn_Rovers_ace_Tom_Cairney_will_not_be_rushed/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=26 February 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> he scored on his return from ankle injury against Brighton & Hove Albion on 1 April 2014, as well as, assisting a goal, in a 3–3 draw.<ref>{{cite news|title=FULL-TIME: Blackburn Rovers 3 Brighton & Hove Albion 3|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/11118903.FULL_TIME__Blackburn_Rovers_3_Brighton___Hove_Albion_3/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=1 April 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> Despite suffering from another injury,<ref>{{cite news|title=TEAM NEWS: Birmingham City v Blackburn Rovers|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/11161580.TEAM_NEWS__Birmingham_City_v_Blackburn_Rovers/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=21 April 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> Cairney returned to the first team, scoring two more goals against [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]]<ref>{{cite news|title=FULL-TIME: Charlton Athletic 1 Blackburn Rovers 3|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/11174906.FULL_TIME__Charlton_Athletic_1_Blackburn_Rovers_3/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=6 May 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> and [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Championship: Blackburn Rovers beat Wigan Athletic 4–3 at Ewood Park|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/blackburn-vs-wigan/report/288207|publisher=Sky Sports|date=3 May 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> Cairney rounded off his successful season when fans voted him Player of the Year 2013–14.<ref name=BlackburnPOTY>{{cite news |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/11190976.Tom_Cairney_named_Blackburn_Rovers__player_of_the_year/ |title=Tom Cairney named Blackburn Rovers' player of the year |first=Paul |last=Wheelock |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=3 May 2014 |accessdate=3 January 2018}}</ref> At the end of the 2013–14 season, Cairney scored 6 times in total of 40 appearances.
In the 2014–15 season, Cairney started the season well when he scored two goals by the end of the first month of the season against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Football League Championship: Blackburn Rovers fight back to draw 1–1 with Cardiff City|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/blackburn-vs-cardiff/report/313767|publisher=Sky Sports|date=12 August 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> and [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] (for this, he won the club's Goal of the Season).<ref>{{cite news|title=Sky Bet Championship: Norwich beat Blackburn 3–1 at Carrow Road|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/norwich-vs-blackburn/report/313798|publisher=Sky Sports|date=20 August 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rovers.co.uk/news/article/markus-olsson-blackburn-rovers-player-of-the-year-2434824.aspx|title=Olsson wins Player of the Year award|publisher=Blackburn Rovers F.C.|date=2 May 2015|accessdate=7 September 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150502151928/http://www.rovers.co.uk/news/article/markus-olsson-blackburn-rovers-player-of-the-year-2434824.aspx|archivedate=7 September 2017|deadurl=yes}}</ref> He continued to play in the central–midfield role for the side<ref>{{cite news|title=Dan Clough column: Cairney can be central to attack-minded Blackburn Rovers|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/11404136.Dan_Clough_column__Cairney_can_be_central_to_attack_minded_Blackburn_Rovers/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=12 August 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> and for that, he was nominated for August's Player of the Month, but lost out to Charlton's [[Igor Vetokele]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Blackburn Rovers star Tom Cairney misses out on Championship player of the month prize|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/11456034.Blackburn_Rovers_star_Tom_Cairney_misses_out_on_Championship_player_of_the_month_prize/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=5 September 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> However, in a 2–1 win over Leeds United on 22 November 2014, Cairney was sent–off for a second bookable.<ref>{{cite news|title=Championship: Jordan Rhodes' penalty earns Blackburn a 2–1 win over Leeds United|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/blackburn-vs-leeds/report/313971|publisher=Sky Sports|date=22 November 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> Shortly after serving his suspension, he then suffered ankle injury.<ref>{{cite news|title=TEAM NEWS: Middlesbrough v Blackburn Rovers|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/11635154.TEAM_NEWS__Middlesbrough_v_Blackburn_Rovers/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=29 November 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Blackburn Rovers hopeful lucky charm Tom Cairney will be fit for Charlton Athletic clash|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/11673804.Blackburn_Rovers_hopeful_lucky_charm_Tom_Cairney_will_be_fit_for_Charlton_Athletic_clash/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=18 December 2014|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> It was not until on 26 December 2014 when he returned from the first team, where he played 69 minutes, in a 2–1 loss against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Bolton Wanderers 2 Blackburn Rovers 1: Hero Heskey's a Christmas cracker – and that's no In April 2018, he was nominated for the EFL Championship Player of the Season award.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43641225|title=EFL awards: Tom Cairney, Ruben Neves & Ryan Sessgenon on Championship shortlist|date=4 April 2018|accessdate=4 April 2018|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 26 May, he scored the only goal against Aston Villa at [[Wembley Stadium]], in the [[2018 EFL Championship play-off Final|2018 Championship play-off Final]] to promote Fulham to the Premier League.<ref name=PO2018>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44178427 |title=Aston Villa 0–1 Fulham |first=Phil |last=Cartwright |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 May 2018 |accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref>
==International career== ===Youth career=== Cairney is eligible to play for Scotland through his Scottish father.<ref name="Cairney Daily Record"/> He continued to be eligible to play for [[England national football team|England]], and his Hull City [[captain (association football)|captain]] [[George Boateng]] described Cairney as being potentially a "huge asset to the national team of England".<ref>{{cite news|title=Boateng criticises Brown but admits players also failed|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/hull_city/8642166.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 April 2010|accessdate=27 April 2010}}</ref> However, he said that his loyalty belongs to Scotland, even if England approached him.<ref name="Cairney Daily Record">{{cite news|title=My miner dad would kill me if I turned out for England, admits Scotland starlet Tom Cairney|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/my-miner-dad-would-kill-me-if-i-turned-1066815 |newspaper=Daily Record |location=Glasgow |date=11 August 2010|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref>{{better source|date=April 2018}}
Cairney was called up by [[Scotland national under-19 football team|Scotland national under-19 team]] for the first time in September 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/scottish_fa_news.cfm?page=1848&newsID=4985|title=U19 Squad to face Iceland|publisher=Scottish Football Association|date=3 September 2009|accessdate=7 September 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170904195801/http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/scottish_fa_news.cfm?page=1848&newsID=4985|archivedate=7 September 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> He made his Scotland U19 debut, where he started and played for 50 minutes before being substituted, in a 3–1 loss against [[Iceland national under-19 football team|Iceland U19]] on 9 September 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=Scotland U19 1–3 Iceland U19|url=http://scottishfa.co.uk/international_fixture_details.cfm?page=1921&matchID=87919|publisher=Scottish Football Association|date=9 September 2009|accessdate=7 September 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170703222112/http://scottishfa.co.uk/international_fixture_details.cfm?page=1921&matchID=87919|archivedate=7 September 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> For the Scotland U19 side, Cairney went on to play two times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/football_player_profile.cfm?page=1848&playerID=181640&squadID=9|publisher=Scottish Football Association|title=Tom Cairney – U19 Squad|accessdate=20 January 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170904200437/http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/football_player_profile.cfm?page=1848&playerID=181640&squadID=9|archivedate=7 September 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Then, on 11 August 2010, Cairney was called up by [[Scotland national under-21 football team|Scotland under-21]] side for the first time<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/scottish_fa_news.cfm?page=1848&newsID=6271|title=Stark calls up young guns for U21 Sweden friendly|publisher=Scottish Football Association|date=11 August 2010|accessdate=7 September 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170904201631/http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/scottish_fa_news.cfm?page=1848&newsID=6271|archivedate=7 September 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> He made his debut for the against [[Sweden national under-21 football team|Sweden]] on 11 August 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/international_fixture_details.cfm?page=1921&matchID=94262|title=Scotland U21 1–1 Sweden U21|publisher=Scottish Football Association|date=11 August 2017|accessdate=7 September 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170904202200/http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/international_fixture_details.cfm?page=1921&matchID=94262|archivedate=7 September 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> Cairney then scored his first Scotland U21 goal on 10 August 2011, in a 3–1 win over [[Norway national under-21 football team|Norway]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/international_fixture_details.cfm?page=1921&matchID=105261|title=Scotland U21 3–1 Norway U21|publisher=Scottish Football Association|date=10 August 2011|accessdate=7 September 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170904202206/http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/international_fixture_details.cfm?page=1921&matchID=105261|archivedate=7 September 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> He made a total of six appearances for the Scotland under-21s between August 2010 and February 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/football_player_profile.cfm?page=1848&playerID=181640&squadID=5 |publisher=Scottish Football Association|title=Tom Cairney – U21 Squad|accessdate=20 January 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170904201956/http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/football_player_profile.cfm?page=1848&playerID=181640&squadID=5|archivedate=7 September 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref>
===Senior team=== Cairney earned his first call up from [[Scotland national football team|Scotland national team]] in March 2017.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ryan Fraser and Tom Cairney earn Scotland squad call-ups|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/10800467/ryan-fraser-and-tom-cairney-earn-scotland-squad-call-ups|publisher=Sky Sports|date=19 March 2017|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> Following his first call up from the senior side, Cairney said he wanted to establish himself in the Scotland national team.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tom Cairney keen to establish himself for Scotland after first call-up|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/10809571/tom-cairney-keen-to-establish-himself-for-scotland-after-first-call-up|publisher=Sky Sports|date=21 March 2017|accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> He made his full international debut in a 1–1 draw with [[Canada men's national soccer team|Canada]] in a [[Exhibition game#Association football|friendly]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Brian|last=McLauchlin|title=Scotland 1–1 Canada|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39275702|publisher=BBC Sport|date=22 March 2017|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref>
